title.narrative: Ukraine BI 2022

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of lifesaving GBV services for women and girls affected by the ongoing emergency in Ukraine

description.narrative:
The project will provide lifesaving GBV prevention, mitigation and response services to women and girls, primarily through psychosocial support (PSS), awareness raising, and referrals provided by trained staff, through a network of 10 mobile outreach teams and 7 Women and Girls Safe Spaces (WGSS). GBV outreach efforts will be paired with the distribution of 8,000 dignity kits (DK), which will provide menstrual and other hygiene items explicitly tailored towards the local needs of women and girls in Ukraine. DK distributions will also be used as a lifesaving entry point to GBV services and referrals. While CVA will not be used in this project, UNFPA 's Implementing Partners will make relevant referrals to CVA actors, based on available service mapping. UNFPA is the UN’s Sexual and Reproductive Health Agency, and in humanitarian settings holds the global-lead mandate to combat GBV and to mitigate its consequences, while also being mandated to meet the reproductive and maternal health needs of persons in emergency situations, ensuring that women can deliver safely in often difficult conditions. The current conflict in Ukraine has caused the largest and fastest growing displacement crisis worldwide. There are now more than 5.2 million refugees (90 per cent of them women and children) and at least 7.7 million internally displaced people (IDPs). Due to the fluid and rapidly changing security situation in Ukraine, which directly impacts IDP movements and spontaneous returns, the need for GBV emergency services has continued to exponentially increase. Both static and mobile GBV service delivery modalities are key to ensure an effective integrated emergency response, to those in most need, throughout the territory of Ukraine including in: hard-to-reach areas locations with heavily impacted infrastructure and densely concentrated IDP areas. GBV prevention, mitigation, and response services are lifesaving, and must be prioritized in the Ukraine response.
To ensure the continuation of existing GBV services, in addition to scaling timely and quality lifesaving response services to meet the immediate needs of women and girls, including in hard-to-reach areas, UNFPA will implement an approach of mobile (using rented vehicles) and static GBV emergency response services. This will enable effective outreach to those in most need, including persons with disabilities (PWD) and older persons.
The targeted locations in this project reflect gaps in current GBV service provision based on UNFPA mapping, which includes municipal-level service mapping. Actual number of GBV survivors and those at risk remains anecdotal at this stage of the emergency.

title.narrative: Ukraine BI 2022

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of immediate lifesaving assistance to the most vulnerable conflict-affected populations through Shelter and Cash programming across Ukraine

description.narrative:
The proposal is linked to the HRP project HUKR22-FSCMS-186566-1 (LFS)
To ensure that non-displaced households, located in the Donetska, Luhanska and Kharkiv Oblasts have access to lifesaving emergency support, NFI will distribute 3,000 Emergency Shelter Kits (ESKs) and 5,000 Non-Food Item (NFI) kits, as part of the Shelter Cluster’s objective of “Sustaining humanitarian activities in areas under threat through the provision of relief items and critical supplies” NRC will implement the Shelter activities through NRC’s established and expanding co-funded network of local partners with operational capacity and access in the target areas, while providing comprehensive transportation and warehousing logistical support, capacity building and access support.
Moreover, considering that from the 24 of February over 7 million people displaced within Ukraine, NRC will complement the emergency response through a cash intervention in the Central and Western Oblasts. As a result of the ongoing war, large parts of the Ukrainian economy have been negatively affected or altogether ceased functioning. To support displaced populations to meet their immediate basic needs, including access to food and essential services such as housing, water and sanitation, health, and education, and reduce negative coping mechanisms, the humanitarian community has identified the scale-up of Multi-purpose Cash Assistance (MPCA) as the preferred rapid response mechanism when feasible. Through this action, NRC proposes to assist 15,400 IDPs with MPCA. To implement at scale and target people on the move despite their changing locations, NRC has developed and will employ a digital system, untethering the geographical scope of the response. Therefore, NRC will reach out to beneficiaries through the recently established Digital Community Hub (DCH). The DCH allows crisis-affected people to connect with NRC, who in turn is able to understand needs and market conditions, and provide simple and innovative services, including information and cash transfers.

title.narrative: Ukraine BI 2022

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency lifesaving assistance to populations affected by conflict in Eastern and Southern Ukraine

description.narrative:
Following UHF third allocation strategy, SI will provide a multi-sectoral response to conflict-affected persons in Kherson, Kharkiv, Luhansk and Donetsk Oblasts. SI will continue to rely on and integrate to the solidarity mechanisms already effective in Ukraine in order not to develop a parallel system. Local associations, municipalities, and networks of volunteers will be supported to ensure a sustainability in the response as well as a scale up to cover additional needs.
In Eastern/Southern Ukraine, directly impacted by the conflict (Kherson, Kharkiv, Luhansk and Donetsk Oblast), SI will contribute to the provision of relief items and critical supplies to the people present both in Governmental Control Areas (GCAs) and Non-Governmental Control Areas (NGCAs). The project will address acute basic needs notably through the distribution of NFI shelter and hygiene kits as well as water supply. In addition, SI will ensure improvements and repairs on water and waste water systems in collective shelters, bomb shelters and/or institutions (health centers, retirement homes, etc.) hosting most vulnerable persons as well as on treatment plants and networks. In collective and bomb shelters, shelter improvements will also be conducted to ensure minimum dignifying living conditions, privacy, and protection of the most vulnerable.
Throughout the assessments conducted since February 2022, SI identified specific vulnerabilities of women, menstruated girls, infants, and elderlies, notably with regards to hygiene needs. Activities will be delivered accordingly. Regarding repairs/rehabilitation of infrastructures and facilities in collective centers and institutions, SI will always intend to ensure accessibility and protection to all, including people with disabilities and elderlies, in the respect of ‘do no harm’.
Ukrainian context is extremely volatile and access constraints are high, mostly in areas targeted by fighting. SI reckons that the situation described in this proposal might change quickly and intends to keep flexibility in its activities and methodologies of implementation to ensure the ability to direct the assistance to the most in need. SI is monitoring the situation and needs in a very close way to ensure permanent adaption of its activities on the field.

title.narrative: Ukraine BI 2022

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of emergency multi-sectoral assistance to the conflict-affected population living in areas under threat, particularly Bakhmutskyi, Kramatorskyi and Pokrovskyi rayons of Donetska oblast, GCA.

description.narrative: The security situation, related to the armed conflict has rapidly deteriorated since the start of the military escalation. A large number of people became IDPs or moved abroad. The population remaining, even those currently not directly affected by security incidents and fighting, are facing reduced or disrupted services. Local authorities’ capacities to provide social protection services are overstretched. There is an increased need for WASH support in conflict-affected areas at both the community and household levels, as well as a need for maintaining the functioning of health infrastructure by procuring and providing supplies such as water tanks, generators, etc. The objective of the proposed project is to address the acute immediate lifesaving and life-sustaining needs of the most vulnerable men, women, boys, and girls living in areas under threat, particularly Bakhmutskyi, Kramatorskyi and Pokrovskyi rayons of Donetska oblast, GCA. Within the framework of the project it is planned to implement the following activities: - Distribution of generators to ensure backup electricity supply and sustained operation of boreholes and pumping stations - Distribution of generators to ensure backup electricity supply of medical institutions - Distribution of materials to local water supply companies, such as pipes, pumps, valves, etc., necessary for emergency repairs of water supply systems in case of damages, including as a result of hostilities - Provision of equipment necessary for pipeline repair - Distribution of Family and PSN hygiene kits for the most vulnerable population, the composition of which is according to recommendations of the WASH Cluster - Distribution of food parcels in addition to hygiene kits - Distribution of bottled water and water trucking in settlements suffering from lack of water - Distribution of tanks and jerry cans for emergency supply of water to social institutions and installation at different points in settlements to provide the population with water in case of a lack of water supply, as well as an emergency stock of water to HHs or small premises, e.g. bomb shelters. It is planned to reach 52,741 people with assistance, including 7,120 people with disabilities. During the project implementation, there might be some challenges related to increased escalation of hostilities, security, access to project locations, procurement and legal obstacles. In this regard, special attention will be paid to risks management. For that purpose, a detailed analysis of potential risks, indicating proposed mitigation measures have been elaborated. NEW WAY (NW) is planning to implement the project on its own. NW is a local NGO that continues activities started in 2016 by German NGO arche noVa. Over the years, NW has become a noticeable actor in the WASH sector, supporting the conflict-affected population through the implementation of relief projects in eastern Ukraine. Furthermore, NW has expertise in the implementation of social infrastructure rehabilitation projects, including the health sector. In particular, similar projects have been implemented with about 5000 individual and institutional hygiene kits distributed, 36 generators provision to educational and healthcare institutions with power from 5 kW to 100 kW, and water and sewage infrastructure rehabilitation in more than 50 settlements of Donetska and Luhanska oblasts. There is a well-established structure as well as necessary technical and support staff in place to oversee the implementation of the project activities. There is a clear awareness of the local context as well as principles of the humanitarian response.

title.narrative: Bureau multipays du HCR en Hongrie
UNHCR Hungary Multi-Country Office

description.narrative: Cette activité montre les détails de Hongrie bureau régional du HCR pour 2022, y compris le budget, les financements, les dépenses et les résultats. Le bureau régional de Hongrie coordonne les activités en Hongrie, en République tchèque et couvre également la République de Moldova, la Slovénie et la Slovaquie.

This activity shows details of the UNHCR Hungary Multi-Country Office for 2022 including the budget, funding, expenditure and results. The Hungary Multi-Country Office coordinates activities in Hungary, the Czech Republic, the Republic of Moldova, the Slovak Republic and Slovenia.

Le HCR, l'Agence des Nations Unies pour les réfugiés, est une organisation internationale qui a pour mission de sauver des vies, de protéger les droits des réfugiés et de construire un avenir meilleur pour les réfugiés, les communautés déplacées et les apatrides.
UNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency, is a global organisation dedicated to saving lives, protecting rights and building a better future for refugees, forcibly displaced communities and stateless people.

reporting-org.narrative: UNICEF

title.narrative: FORMULATION OF EQUITABLE CHILD FRIENDLYPOLICIES

description.narrative: By 2022, the Government and Parliament stakeholders have increased capacity to formulate equitable child-friendly policies, which contributes to Access To Inclusive Social Protection, Reducing Child Poverty, Reducing Child Poverty (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, evidence-driven, integrated and equitable social protection policies, efficient financial allocations and family-friendly local service provision are in place to address the social exclusion of children in Ukraine

description.narrative: Evidence generation on child deprivations and convening partnerships around child poverty reduction was the groundbreaking progress of the year. condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2022, vulnerable families with children and those with children with delays and disabilities have access to social services inselected communities, including in humanitarian settings

description.narrative: Vulnerable families with children including IDPs continue to have limited access to social services, especially in Eastern Ukraine. Through humanitarian, recovery and development programmes, UNICEF ;enhanced ;the capacity of professionals and caregivers on child protection issues and ensured child and family-centered services. In 2021, the child protection humanitarian program reached around 45,500 children and caregivers with psycho-social and child protection activities. ;Child welfare- related tools and best practice models developed on integrated social services wereare documented and shared with the Ministry of Social Policy and other national stakeholders for further replication under the on-going decentralization reforms.; | Status:On-track | As-of Date:24/01/2022

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2022, legal framework is in place and Government and other stakeholders have increased capacity to implement the child-friendlyjustice system

description.narrative: In 2021, the Justice for Children Reform continued to be a priority. The draft Law on Child-Friendly Justice developed with UNICEF support was submitted to the Parliament for adoption. UNICEF supported two strategic models - the Restorative Justice Programme for juveniles in conflict with the law and the Barnahus model for child-victims and witnesses of violence. UNICEF further invested in capacity strengthening of Justice sector professionals based on the Unified Standards. Moreover, the rehabilitation/resocialization programme for juveniles in conflict with the law was institutionalized.;UNICEF continued smooth coordination among;stakeholders within the Inter-Agency Coordination Council on Justice for Children. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:24/01/2022

title.narrative: By 2022, children without parental care and at risk of institutionalization have access to family support and /or family substitutecare based on standards and guidelines

description.narrative: Ukraine remains one of the countries in Europe with high number of children in institutional care (1.2% of the child population in institutions in 2020). ; UNICEF continues its advocacy for a comprehensive child welfare,DIreform and further strengthening of the national “gatekeeping” system at all levels. Meanwhile, UNICEF and partners continue to work on strengthening the existing alternative care system, as well as introducing new family-type alternative care forms, capacity development of ;socialworkforce, and expanding policy dialogue at national and sub-national levels aiming to further influence the national policies in the area of alternative childcare.; | Status:On-track | As-of Date:24/01/2022

title.narrative: QUALITY INTEGRATED MCH INTERVENTIONS, INCLUDING IMMUNIZATION, NUTRITION SERVICES

description.narrative: By 2022, MOH and selected regional health care authorities and professionals, including conflict-affected districts, have increased capacity to provide quality integrated MCH services, including immunization and nutrition services., which contributes to Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence (Covid), Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care (Covid), Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, all children and pregnant women in Ukraine, including in situations of humanitarian crisis, utilize improved quality and affordable mother and child health-care services.

related-activity.ref: 4410/A0/05/884 IMPROVED QUALITY AND AFFORDABLE MOTHER AND CHILD HEALTH-CARE SERVICES

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2022, MOH and selected regional health care authorities and professionals, including conflict-affected districts, have increasedcapacity to provide quality integrated MCH services, including immunization and nutrition services.

description.narrative: In 2021,UNICEF increased support to mother and child healthcare (MCHC) services as part of the COVID-19 response and in the context of the health care reform. UNICEF took a proactive role in addressing the negative impact of the pandemic on the national health care system by providing technical assistance for the adoption and implementation of the Universal-Progressive Home Visiting model and systemic strengthening at the primary health care level, capacity development, strengthening of vaccine management, including vaccine logistics and cold chain equipment support. Advocacy and support for continuous immunization services increased including in non-government-controlled areas. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:23/01/2022

description.narrative: By 2022, children and caregivers have access to violence prevention, reporting and response mechanisms, which contributes to Cross Sectoral - Gender Discriminatory Roles And Practices, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement, Promotion Of Care, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being And Justice, Protection From Violence, Exploitation, Abuse And Neglect. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, the most vulnerable children in Ukraine benefit from more-child-friendly and family-oriented social welfare and justice systems.

related-activity.ref: 4410/A0/05/882 CHILD-FRIENDLY AND FAMILY-ORIENTED SOCIAL WELFARE AND JUSTICE SYSTEMS

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2022, children and caregivers have access to violence prevention, reporting and response mechanisms

description.narrative: The issue of Violence Against Children continued to be a priority for UNICEF and national partners in 2021. UNICEF’s advocacy resulted in prioritization of specialized services for child-victims and witnesses of violence such as application of the Barnahus model. The Barnahus model brings in a new strategic approach to child-friendly judicial and protection procedures and is of interest for national and sub-national authorities. In addition, UNICEF expanded its’ positive parenting programs aiming to prevent violence against children, continued GBV services in the East and contributed to initiatives in the area of on-line protection.; | Status:On-track | As-of Date:24/01/2022

description.narrative: Despite global COVID-19 pandemic, the Government of Ukraine remained committed to implement education reform agenda aimed to sustain and improve learning outcomes and remove barriers constraining access to quality competency-based education for children and adolescents. description.narrative: In 2021 UNICEF with education in emergency (EiE) response have reached 27,900 school and preschool age girls and boys in Non-Government Controlled Area (NGCA) and in areas along the contact line in Government Controlled Area (GCA), providing them with educational supplies, rehabilitating schools that are in most critical need, and building capacity of teachers on identified priority topics, including Life Skills Education (LSE), Conflict Sensitive Education (CSE), Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR). In August 2021, Government of Ukraine has approved the Safe Schools Declaration (SSD) Implementation Plan, translating commitment into action and supporting education in emergencies. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:23/01/2022

description.narrative: By 2022, adolescents and youth increased skills and competencies to be adequately prepared for adult life as active citizens and for the world of work., which contributes to Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Communications, Advocacy And Public Engagement, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Innovation, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, all children and adolescents in Ukraine, especially those disadvantaged and affected by the conflict, access inclusive and quality school education and early learning while enjoying opportunities for meaningful participation and civic engagement.

related-activity.ref: 4410/A0/05/883 INCLUSIVE AND QUALITY SCHOOL EDUCATION AND EARLY LEARNING

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2022, adolescents and youth increased skills and competencies to be adequately prepared for adult life as active citizens andfor the world of work.

description.narrative: UNICEF in partnership with MoYS, MoES, MEEP, CSOs and private sector supported young people’s empowerment as advocates and innovators, while providing support for improving their emotional health and acquiring skills for adult life and the labor market. UNICEF provided skills-building opportunities for 6,360 young people (56% girls) and engaged 59,428 youth (73% girls) as leaders or participants of civic initiatives, including 16,514 who contributed to climate change action through campaigning, designing solution or peer engagement. Enhanced by UNICEF-supported digital platform, peer counsellors provided emotional support to 6,930 adolescents. UPSHIFT was adapted for vocational education institutions;and piloted in 10 facilities. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:23/01/2022

description.narrative: UNICEF’s convening power and technical contribution on data have brought all stakeholders both at national and local levels closer to children’s needs. title.narrative: Social & Behaviour Change, AAP Response to Ukraine crisis

reporting-org.narrative: Cordaid

title.narrative: Acute Joint Response - Ukraine

description.narrative: Active conflict is ongoing in and around Eastern Ukraine since 2014, but over the past months tensions between Russia and Ukraine have increased significantly. This has resulted in a Russian invasion of Ukraine in the early hours of Feb 24. Russia has attacked Ukraine by air, land and sea, threatening the lives and livelihoods of many people. OCHA reports at least 550 civilian casualties (OCHA, 1/3), but the real number is expected to be much higher and to increase further. Infrastructure has also been affected: houses, water systems, power supply and road networks have been damaged, and people in active conflict areas are seeking shelter underground. Prices have increased drastically, and there is a shortage of basic supplies and services, amongst others food, water and health care.

Activities are tailored to the specific needs of the people directly affected by the conflict, supporting both IDPs and families remaining home. Caritas will provide assistance to all conflict affected people, but special attention is given to women and children, elderly and people with disabilities (PWD), as well as IDPs, large families, families run by single parents, and children alone. Women and children are often travelling without the adult men of the family, who have to be available for the army, increasing their protection risk. For elderly and PWD it is more difficult to flee the active conflict areas and they may be forced to stay.
The main objective of the project is to provide basic emergency assistance to most vulnerable people, affected by the conflict.

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Humanitarian Aid Corporate Indicators
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

title.narrative: FSC-I2: Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs (non-cash)

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof with objective to ensure immediate access to the necessary food commodities. This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

title.narrative: SHL-I4: Number of people provided with non-food items (other than hygiene/dignity kits)

description.narrative: Distribution of Non-Food Items. All household materials excluding those that fall under hygiene/dignity kits or direct shelter items. Also excludes unrestricted cash, which is to be put under indicator CSH-I1 or CSH-I2. However, if cash is provided for the purpose of buying household items, it should be put under this indicator (i.e. restricted cash).

title.narrative: Water Supply
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

title.narrative: Availability of, access to and consumption of food
FSC-I2: Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs (non-cash)

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof with objective to ensure immediate access to the necessary food commodities. This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

title.narrative: Hygiene promotion
WSH-I1: Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: Regular and timely access: 250g soap/p/m for personal hygiene, 200g soap/p/month for laundry. This includes hygiene/dignity kits. Access may be in-kind or though voucher distribution or through unconditional restricted cash to enable beneficiary to buy soap (without compromising access to other basic needs). Distributed items need to be culturally acceptable i.e. take into account local practice and expectations.

description.narrative: Distribution of Non-Food Items. All household materials excluding those that fall under hygiene/dignity kits or direct shelter items. Also excludes unrestricted cash, which is to be put under indicator CSH-I1 or CSH-I2. However, if cash is provided for the purpose of buying household items, it should be put under this indicator (i.e. restricted cash).

reporting-org.narrative: Cordaid

title.narrative: SHO campaign for Ukraine

description.narrative: All Ukrainians in Ukraine in need of basis support and later on early recovery support; Ukrainians who have fled the country towards Poland, Moldova or another adjacent country, and are in need of basic support.

In the early hours of 24th February 2022 Russian forces launched major cross-border attacks against Ukraine from the north, east and south, by land, sea and air. Major attacks have been reported across Ukraine, including in the capital Kyiv, creating growing sense of fear and panic that forced many people into bomb shelters and subways. People in the capital, east and south of the country are fleeing towards Ukraine’s western regions and are entering neighbouring European countries, as well as into Russia. As of 09/032022 UNHCR estimates that 2mln people have already fled to neighbouring countries like Moldova, Romania, Poland and Hungary, and 1mln people are internally displaced. And it is expected that more people will flee or get displaced during the coming period. The current crisis carries significant implications for a country already experiencing a humanitarian crisis with 2.9 million people dependent on humanitarian assistance, linked to the ongoing conflict after pro-Russian separatists took control over parts of the eastern Donbas region in 2014. In the morning of 9 March certain humanitarian corridors were agreed to by the Russian Federation and the Government of Ukraine. Evacuation has begun in the north-eastern city of Sumy. Early reports indicate there continue to be issues with evacuations of the cities of Bucha, Gostomel and Mariupul. Humanitarian corridors have been set up around several cities, however, they have not been respected by Russia, making it very complicated to savely evacuate people, as well as to get aid supplies into the cities.
Providing lifesaving and early recovery support to Ukrainians that are internally displaced as well as to provide basic lifesaving support to those seeking refuge in countries adjacent to Ukraine.

reporting-org.narrative: UNOCHA - Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

title.narrative: Ensuring access to lifesaving health and nutrition, water sanitation and hygiene, child protection, education and cash assistance, supplies and services for children and families in Ukraine

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to address immediate needs in Health, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), Child Protection, and Education in eastern, western and central Ukraine. This UNICEF project 1) provides critical health supplies and medicines to local hospitals, 2) provides micro-nutrient supplements to children and mothers, 3) repairs water resources and provides WASH supplies, 4) provides teaching and learning materials and 5) provides $480,000 in multi-purpose cash among other activities. The project provides assistance to 72,000 people including 26,000 men, 33,000 women, 13,000 children, and including 1,500 persons with disabilities.

title.narrative: Ensuring access to lifesaving health and nutrition, water sanitation and hygiene, child protection, education and cash assistance, supplies and services for children and families in Ukraine

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to address the immediate and lifesaving needs on Health, WASH, Child Protection, and Education in eastern, western and central Ukraine. This UNICEF project 1) provides critical health supplies and medicines to local hospitals, 2) provides micro-nutrient supplements to children and mothers, 3) repairs water resources and provides WASH supplies, 4) provides teaching and learning materials and 5) provides $721,865 in multi-purpose cash among other activities. The project provides life-saving assistance to 108,000 people, including 38,880 men, 49,680 women, 13,500 children, and 2,159 persons with disabilities.

This UNHCR project will 1) provide blankets, sleeping bags to 10,000 people, 2) provide multi-purpose cash to 1,800 people and 3) assist 2,000 Persons of Concern with civil status registration or documentation. The project provides life-saving assistance to 12,500 people including 2,500 men, 5,000 women, 5,000 children and 1,250 persons with disabilities.

title.narrative: Output 3

description.narrative: Ensure access to basic needs and reduction of protection risks through the distribution of multi-purpose cash assistanceUNHCR will provide multi-purpose cash assistance to IDPs in Ukraine. The cash will be delivered directly by UNHCR, with support from partners with registration in proGres V4. Registration desks will be embedded in local reception centres established by the authorities. This is currently being implemented in Lviv and will shortly be expanded to Vinnytsia and Uzhhorod. UNHCR will assess the viability of delivering in other locations as security conditions allow.

title.narrative: Output 1

description.narrative: Protection AssistanceThe protection situation in Ukraine is extremely volatile and requires the scaling up of services for persons with specific needs that UNHCR has been already providing in eastern Ukraine. UNHCR, through partners, will provide case management support in reception centres, in IDP communities and in conflict-affected communities. UNHCR, as protection cluster lead, will work to ensure access to protection services, referring persons with specific needs to State services, or where not available, to humanitarian assistance offered by UNHCR and partners. This will include enrolment for multi-purpose cash assistance.UNHCR and its partners will provide social accompaniment, a distinctly process-based approach aimed at providing comprehensive assistance to displaced and other persons affected by the military offensive who are incapable of independently exercising their rights due to various limitations that goes above and beyond the standard protection counselling session. UNHCR is scaling up its provision of psychosocial support, considering its experience in providing psycho-social support through non-specialized PSS services on both sides of the contact line in eastern Ukraine. The already existing needs for psychosocial support caused by the prolonged conflict in eastern Ukraine have multiplied and intensified and are now critical. The military offensive across the country generates traumatic experiences and chronic stress, influences the mental health and psychosocial well-being of the affected and displaced population across Ukraine. Through its partners in UNHCR is planning on providing urgent non-specialized support (third level of the pyramid in the IASC Guidelines on Mental Health and Psycho-social Support in Emergency Situations).

title.narrative: Indicator 1.1

description.narrative: PP.1a Number of protection referral mechanisms and/or pathways established and regularly updated (# of people receiving PSS, social accompaniment and case management support, including CBI enrolment)

title.narrative: Output 2

description.narrative: Shelter and NFI assistance UNHCR will provide emergency shelter repair kits to conflict-affected households with homes damaged during the current military offensive. The shelter kits will allow for households to carry-out provisional repairs to protect them against the freezing cold and elements, until more durable repairs are feasible. UNHCR is prepositioning stocks in central Ukraine and coordinating closely with international organizations on the delivery of this assistance through humanitarian corridors.UNHCR will also provide core relief items, including blankets, mattresses, linens, folding beds, kitchen sets, jerry cans, buckets and solar lamps to IDPs and conflict-affected people in need to meet their most basic needs. These items will be important for those sheltering in place in conflict-affected areas, in ill-equipped bunkers, as well as for the displaced, including those in reception and collective centres.

title.narrative: CERF health emergency response to the escalation of the conflict in Ukraine – delivery of critical medical items and strengthening of the surveillance system

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to establish a logistic hub and an airbridge of essential supplies, establish out-country and in-country trucking capacity and reinforce health information and surveillance systems across the country. This WHO project will 1) operate aerial rotations, 2) procure and distribute medical supplies (kits and other critical items) and infrastructure equipment (generators) and 3) design and implement a health information system to support health facilities among other activities. The project provides life-saving assistance to 950,000 people including 456,000 men, 304,000 women, 190,000 children and 123,500 persons with disabilities.

reporting-org.narrative: Plan International Netherlands

title.narrative: Ukraine Emergency Response SHO Dutch Appeal 2022

description.narrative:
SUMMARY Aid organizations are very concerned about the consequences of the large-scale hostilities in Ukraine. Ukrainians are massively fleeing the country and seeking protection in neighbouring countries. Families are separated from each other. For those who are left behind, the situation is life-threatening and extremely uncertain. They urgently need help. In exceptional disasters, 11 Dutch collaborating aid organizations join forces under Giro555. These aid organizations include: Stiching Vluchteling, Cordaid, CARE Nederland, Kerk in Actie, Oxfam Novib, Save the Children, UNICEF, Dut
This funding will be used to provide protection, MHPSS and CVA to children, adolescent and caregiver refugees from Ukraine in Poland, in particular through two one-stop shop reception centres. One in Opole and one in Warsaw, and through mobile units with a reach throughout the affected areas of the country. Additionally, the project will fund a study on localisation in the context of the Ukraine and Poland.

reporting-org.narrative: International Organization for Migration (IOM)

title.narrative: Everyone Counts - Inclusive Data for Stability and Development

description.narrative: In close partnership with the Ministry for Communities and Territories Development of Ukraine and the State Statistics Services of Ukraine, as well as with territorial communities themselves, IOM will facilitate the enhancement of gender-sensitive data gathering capacities at the local level in Ukraine, and creation of a grassroots data gathering “network” in support of local preparedness and resilience, including by engaging youth, women and civil society in reporting on the emergency-, recovery-, and stability-related needs of their communities, and by building local capacity for evidence-based and gender-sensitive policy-making.

title.narrative: Emergency Response to the Conflict in Ukraine through Multi-Purpose Cash, Shelter and Non-food Items

description.narrative: IOM aims to provide lifesaving assistance through shelter, non-food items, and multi-purpose cash assistance for the most vulnerable people affected by the ongoing hostilities, particularly women, children, older persons and persons living with disabilities and/or chronic diseases. This project maintains and restores the dignity of people affected by conflict, addresses the essential needs of the most vulnerable people when they are unable to do so themselves because of the ongoing hostilities and the loss of livelihoods, and mitigates protection risks.

reporting-org.narrative: International Organization for Migration (IOM)

title.narrative: Assistance to the Transfer of Ukrainians to Long Term Accommodation in Ireland

description.narrative: The project aims to contribute to the implementation of the temporary protection directive with a focus on supporting long term accommodation for Ukrainians and third country nationals (TCNs) having entered Ireland since 24 February 2022. The project will facilitate the safe and orderly movement and transportation facility of Ukrainians and TCNs to their long-term accommodation and manage an effective tracking system. This will include the provision of movement support to Ukrainian nationals and TCNs, from their current short-term accommodation in Ireland to the long-term solutions. It will also support Ukrainian nationals and TCNs to be supported with their immediate needs when settling into a new house and assist in pre departure group orientation from the hotel and vulnerability screening when required for onward referral to relevant local institutions as regards their protection and security needs.

title.narrative: Enhancing the Response to Ukraine Crisis-Affected Persons in Moldova

description.narrative: The overall objective of this project is to enhance the response to those crossing the Moldovan borders as a result of the ongoing crisis in Ukraine. This project complements Moldovan authorities’ ongoing efforts to address the humanitarian needs by collecting, analysing and providing critical information to the authorities and donors for a better targeted response; procuring critical non-food items for those most in need; and strengthening the operational capacity of local border authorities to ensure the swift and dignified processing of conflict-affected people incoming from Ukraine.

title.narrative: Enhancing Stakeholders’ Preparedness to Address Immediate Humanitarian Needs in Case of Rapid Onset Emergencies, Ukraine

description.narrative: The most recent tensions over Ukraine and dynamic events in the country increase the likelihood of a substantial escalation of the conflict. In response to the evolving humanitarian crisis in Ukraine the project is aimed at prepositioning of essential shelter, water, sanitation and hygiene, and non-food item kits and their distribution to most vulnerable displaced and other conflict-affected individuals, building local authorities and civil society capacities on displacement management in urban contexts through training of trainers, practitioners and decision makers, as well as provision of collective centre management equipment and stop-gap provision of multipurpose cash assistance to vulnerable displaced and other conflict-affected individuals.

reporting-org.narrative: International Organization for Migration (IOM)

title.narrative: Prepositioning and Distribution of Critical Winterization Support for Most Vulnerable Communities in the Eastern Conflict Area of Ukraine

description.narrative: Almost eight years after the onset of the crisis in eastern Ukraine, the conflict continues at an overall low intensity on both sides of the Line of Contact (LoC) that separates the Government-Controlled Areas (GCA) and the Non-Government-Controlled Areas (NGCA). While the overall situation has slightly improved in the GCA since the beginning of the conflict, pockets of poverty and extreme needs remain all along the LoC, compounded by an overall dysfunctional, ill equipped and poorly funded system for provision of essential services. Through this grant, IOM is receiving and prepositioning high thermal blankets for three months in Kyiv, part of USAID’s Bureau of Humanitarian Assistant (BHA) in-kind donation. In case of rapid onset crises, in coordination with local authorities and relevant humanitarian actors through the Shelter/NFIs Cluster and its Winterization Working Group, IOM will use the blanket stocks to readily deliver essential winterization assistance to displaced families and/or other conflict-affected households and individuals in need.

reporting-org.narrative: International Organization for Migration (IOM)

title.narrative: Voluntary Humanitarian Return for Third Country Nationals Fleeing Ukraine to Neighboring Countries

description.narrative: Voluntary humanitarian return and related assistance will be facilitated for approximately 660 third country nationals (TCN) fleeing Ukraine in the following host countries: Poland, Romania, and Slovakia. IOM will assist TCN in need of return assistance who avail themselves of this support on a voluntary basis and non-discriminatory manner. IOM will leverage its existing expertise in movement management overall and humanitarian returns in particular to ensure safe, orderly, and dignified return. IOM will provide support through a mixed approach, prioritizing collective (charter) movements as relevant for larger caseloads as well as individualized processing for those that require more individualized assistance. IOM will adapt in each host country its operating return procedures, in close coordination with respective national authorities.

reporting-org.narrative: International Organization for Migration (IOM)

title.narrative: Addressing Immediate Humanitarian Needs of the Most Vulnerable Populations in Ukraine

description.narrative: On 24 February 2022, a broad military offensive caused rapid deterioration of the security situation across Ukraine. The intense hostilities, both along the Line of Contact and new areas throughout Ukraine, including Kyiv, have resulted in the loss of lives, injuries, damages to civilian and public infrastructure, and mass displacement of the population throughout the country and to the neighbouring countries. According to the 2022 UN Flash Appeal for Ukraine, 18 million people are projected to be affected, including up to 6.7 million people anticipated to be newly internally displaced. Of the affected population, 12 million people are expected to need urgent humanitarian assistance. Instances of sexual assault and disappearances are also being reported. Through this intervention, IOM aims to provide lifesaving assistance through non-food items, addressing emergency shelter needs, namely damage caused by shelling, and humanitarian transportation support/protection assistance for the affected population in Ukraine. The project is specifically targeting the most vulnerable population affected by the ongoing hostilities, particularly women, children, older persons and persons living with disabilities and/or chronic diseases.

title.narrative: OTP 8 - UKRAINE EMERGENCY RESPONSE

description.narrative: New Element, which contributes to Access To Inclusive Social Protection, Access To Quality Learning Opportunities, Communication And Advocacy, Cross-Sectoral - Monitoring, Data And Situation Analyses, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Operations Support To Programme Delivery, Promotion Of Care, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being And Justice, Protection From Violence, Exploitation, Abuse And Neglect, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions, Supply And Logistics. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Communications, Data, Research, Evaluation And Knowledge Management, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Risk-Informed Humanitarian And Development Nexus Programming, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, Moldova national systems and services are more inclusive, able to protect the rights of children, and respond to the needs of the most vulnerable in an equitable way

title.narrative: National appeal 'Samen in actie voor Oekraine' (Together for Ukraine)

description.narrative: On February 24th the conflict in Ukraine escalated. In just 2 months thousands have been killed and injured and over 7,7 million people are displaced. Almost 6 million refugees have left Ukraine and the number is still growing. With a state of emergency declared and men between the ages of 18 and 60 having to stay to fight, many displaced women and children are left alone. The damage of houses, schools, hospitals and other services and infrastructure is extensive. Direct aid is needed for people who are hit by the events in Ukraine and for the refugees in neighbouring countries. There is a need for shelter, medical and psychosocial care, food and clean drinking water.
